Award.AwardTitle: Assessing poverty dynamics in an arid agrarian context--pre-Saharan Morocco

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research is a two-year interdisciplinary project between an anthropologist (the PI) and an agricultural economist at the University of Kentucky (Dr. Yoko Kusunose). The purpose is to explore the determinants of upward economic mobility and chronic poverty in an oasis valley of southern Morocco and builds on the ethnographic fieldwork conducted for the Fellow's PhD in cultural anthropology at the University of Kentucky. The goals of the research are to: 1) empirically test a model of poverty dynamics developed through ethnographic field methods and a small sample of household case studies; 2) use the tools of economic poverty analysis to explain which households in the Mgoun valley experienced upward mobility or chronic poverty and why; and 3) use empirical, economic and qualitative, anthropological approaches to offer an explanation of vulnerability to poverty that places household strategies to manage income and assets in the context of broader structural and temporal processes. The hypothesis is that multiple stable equilibria--divergent and stable trajectories of capital accumulation for some and chronic poverty for others--have emerged for households in the Mgoun valley of Morocco. The primary research method is a survey of 300 household heads from
throughout the Mgoun valley. The survey will use current and recall data on income, assets, demographic, and livelihoods to test the representativeness of previous research findings and yield new insights about poverty dynamics in this arid agrarian context. Households will be chosen through stratified random sampling techniques. This survey will allow for econometric analysis with the support of the faculty mentor. Complementary anthropological methods such as open and semi-structured interviewing will provide context for the survey data. The data collection and poverty analysis necessary for the project rely on an interdisciplinary collaboration between the quantitative techniques from economics and the anthropological emphasis on complex determinants of social and economic transformation.

Intellectual merit:

The proposed project addresses one of the four topic areas of interest outlined in
the NSF report "Rebuilding the Mosaic": sources of social and economic disparities and processes that alleviate those disparities. It examines sources of disparity in a marginalized arid zone of a strategically important region of the world, North Africa and the Middle East. The research will contribute empirical and theoretical insights into how upward socio-economic mobility of some household may improve overall standards of living but also produces new forms of economic inequality. This contribution, though emerging from data specific to southern Morocco, will be applicable to other situations where migration and arid land agriculture are prominent features of the livelihood systems.

Broader impacts:

Conclusions from this research will be presented to Moroccan policymakers and researchers with the goal of enhancing official understanding of poverty dynamics at the household and community level. This research also has applied implications for development agencies, policymakers, and applied research institutes engaged in broader policy dialogues about how to support rural livelihoods and poverty alleviation efforts. The proposed project uses new theories of poverty dynamics--specifically how a dynamic view of poverty traps predicts who will or will not escape chronic deprivation--to explore how processes of upward mobility can occur outside of government agricultural development or poverty alleviation policies. In the case of southern Morocco, the use of remittances to support the emergence of small-scale commercial agriculture was a largely informal process driven by the migrants and their families, not official programs, but it also engendered new patterns of inequality. This is an important finding with implications for migration policy, poverty alleviation efforts, and our understanding of the role of agriculture in the diversified livelihood portfolios of the marginalized rural poor in arid settings around the world.

In addition, this being a postdoctoral fellowship project, it embodies integration of research, training and education. The project facilitates the Fellow's future career development in the emerging interdisciplinary fields of research within the social, behavioral and economic sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored household strategies to confront poverty, including labor migration, diversifying their livelihoods, and adjusting their agricultural methods. The specific goal was to test a model of poverty dynamics in an arid, agrarian context that the co-PI initially developed through qualitative, ethnographic field methods and a small sample of household case studies.  We conducted a household survey of 318 households in the Mgoun Valley, gathering data on present-day household assets, livelihoods, and characteristics, on self-reported migration and remitting histories, and on pre-migration, or ‘baseline’ household assets and characteristics. We developed hypotheses for the quantitative study based on the ethnographic research: 1) households that had international migrants in the early 1960s used remittances to make long-term investments that resulted in higher asset levels and human capital formation in 2014 than households without international migration experience; 2) migration promoted greater equity in land ownership, as formerly land-poor, subjugated households invested in land while formerly land-rich, higher status households either divested or did not increase their holdings. Ethnographic research revealed that a central priority for the household heads at the end of their careers was to transfer the increased standard of living derived from migration onto the next generation. While all households developed diversified livelihoods in the contemporary period, we hypothesized that international migrant households’ would pass along the benefits of their long-term investments to the next generation in the form of higher levels of education (especially vocational training and apprenticeship in lucrative trades) and higher asset ownership of both traditional markers of status (land and livestock) and ‘new economy’ assets such as business enterprises and other productive assets. These investment strategies differed based on the initial assets owned by the migrating household.

 

Our results indicated that migration event initiated decades-long streams of steady income in the forms of remittances and pension checks. Accompanying household-level empirical analysis shows that this afforded the migrant-sending households a foothold in the ‘new’ economy: Households invested in vocational training, secondary schooling, and business ownership at rates higher than their non-sending counterparts. Migration also hastened the transition of households out of the ‘old economy’—land and livestock ownership declined for migrant-sending households, particularly those owning more land. We also document that the migration event was unusually open—work in the coal mines was open to virtually anyone—meaning that the recruits came from across the entire class- and economic spectrum. The combination of an unusually low entry cost and the resultant provision of a large and long flow of cash meant that overall, migration was an equalizing force in the economy.  We also documented changes in the role of agriculture in rural residents’ livelihoods, especially its continuing economic importance but a shift towards high-value tree crops. These changes influenced the development of local labor markets, which integrated waged work and diverse labor arrangements to support continued agricultural production in the context of high-levels of out migration.

 

Study results impact the sub-fields of poverty and migration studies, advancing theory about the long-term wealth effects of migration. It also advances agrarian studies--the analysis of agri-food systems and agro-ecology--by exploring how diversified livelihoods can promote investments in small-scale farming. The interdisciplinary work conducted for this project also impacts the more qualitative field of anthropology, showing the possibility for mixed methods and critical approaches to quantitative analysis. Finally, this research has important implications for how migration policy may promote or hinder household-level wealth accumulation strategies. It sheds light on how agriculture policy might support the long-term investment of remittance funds into productive activities in resource-poor areas.
